Be consistent with tabs here and all over.
done

Seems weird to have to mess with `sockaddr_un` just to construct the socket name. Can we refactor the `console_socket_path` to output into a `socket_path_t` without the leading \0,  instead of filling out a `sockaddr_un`? Then there would be no need for `console_socket_path_readable` nor `console_socket_get_path`.

And either way, I think we should just allocate the socket name in the `console` so we only do this work once instead of on every D-Bus property read.

I like your idea of saving socket_name in the console. I added that. I have removed my new function called console_socket_get_path. I did not change existing console_socket* functions as those are called in client code too.

I didn't see any restriction on the length of `console_id`. Probably want to use snprintf then and check for overflow.

`console_id` might also be `NULL` - need to handle that case.

good catch on length check. Added the check.
Now changed the logic and console_id can not be null.
Was this duplicated by accident?
yes, Sorry about that. Removed.
The interesting part is truncated. Perhaps just show a get-property on this one prop instead of the whole introspect.
Done
Please rebase this on current master in addition to addressing Jonathan's comments.
Done
should be `>=`
Done
Should be `>=`
Done
looks OK assuming the d-bus interface is approved
It has been merged: https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/phosphor-dbus-interfaces/+/61486

DBus is starting to become more tightly integrated into the obmc-console implementation. I think it should probably still be easy to disable it. I feel that we should probably start isolate the DBus related code into its own file which can be compiled in or out as required by the build configuration.
Marking as -1 to counteract Jonathan's +1 for now 😊
Done

I probably should have been more explicit here. Moving code to a separate file and changing the code's behaviour in the one patch makes the work very difficult to review.

I would like to see this as two patches:

1. Move the code out to a separate file (`console-dbus.c` as you've used here is fine).
2. Rework the code to change the DBus behaviour at runtime

This allows others to better inspect how the behaviour has changed in the diff of 2.

The trick to getting things merged is to make it hard for a maintainer to say no, rather than merely making it possible for a maintainer to say yes. Patches that are more difficult to review than is necessary are an easy "no" 😊
Added 2 more commits.

Please let's not register multiple well-known bus names for the one connection.

We already have a bus name registered at line 490.

Having said that, there can be multiple instances of `obmc-console-server`, and the currently registered bus name does not incorporate anything to distinguish it from any other instance. So the current behaviour is broken. I recognise this is not your fault. However, we do need to fix it, and I think the time has come.

Further, the bus name request should happen only after we've initialised all objects to be presented on the connection - this is a requirement if we are to interact sensibly with the rest of the DBus components in the system.

Thus, IMO the request on 490 should be deleted in favour of this new request on 521. However, this is likely a breaking change on systems with only a single console. We need to put some effort in to determine whether any other applications in the OpenBMC ecosystem is accessing the obmc-console-server instance through this existing bus name (the `DBUS_NAME` constant). If there are, then these applications will need to be fixed. The fix is probably best done by having any dependent applications look up the connection through the mapper.

A stretch goal is to get the interface that allows configuration of the TTY (such as baud rate) defined in phosphor-dbus-interfaces.

Removed original BUS name and moved buadrate and setBaudRate under new BUS name.
The old property is not used by anyone.

I will update phosphor-dbus-interface once you are ok with this.
This is a bit of a maze, and I think it would be improved by refactoring `console_socket_path()` take a pointer to a `socket_path_t` into which it renders the socket name.
Done

Hi Ninad,

Sorry about not being as explicit as I maybe should have on the previous review. I've left some comments that hopefully clear things up.

This changes the interface under which the baud rate was hosted as well, which is something we should avoid for now. The baud rate controls need to stay defined on the old interface, but on the new object.

The old interface name was `xyz.openbmc_project.console`. The old code was terrible and conflated the bus name and the interface name in the `DBUS_NAME` macro. We need them to be separate now.

Specifically, for the baud rate, this change nees:

1. Bus name of `xyz.openbmc_project.Console.<socket-id>`
2. Object name of `/xyz/openbmc_project/Console/<socket-id>`
3. Interface name of `xyz.openbmc_project.console` (the old interface name).

(A DBus object implementing multiple DBus interfaces is normal practice)
Done

I probably should have been more explicit here also.

This change makes the API harder to use correctly. I don't think this is what we want. For instance, you're now having to pass `NULL` at some call-sites, which is an indication we've got something wrong.

Rusty's API scale is a great reference:

1. [How Do I Make This Hard to Misuse?](https://ozlabs.org/~rusty/index.cgi/tech/2008-03-30.html)
2. [What If I Don't Actually Like My Users?](https://ozlabs.org/~rusty/index.cgi/tech/2008-04-01.html)

In terms of what we're doing here, I think a better prototype might be:

```
ssize_t console_socket_path(socket_path_t path, const char *id);
```

Then, when populating the `struct sockaddr_un` we can call it like:

```
rc = console_socket_path(addr.sun_path, config_get_value(config, "socket-id"));
```

or if we're populating the field in the `struct console` instance:

```
rc = console_socket_path(console->socket_name, config_get_value(config, "socket-id"));
```
Done
Do these examples need an update given some of the other discussion about bus connection names and object paths?
No, the interface for new stuff is same. I modified comment in the other commit where interface was changed.
This is easier to agree with, thanks for splitting the changes up! However, a few remaining comments.

I think whether we do this is still pending on the discussion with the bmcweb maintainers, given it was their choice to expose the endpoint this way. I think the onus on maintaining that backwards compatibility should be with bmcweb.
Yes, that is a next step but right now it is required as we enforce the value.
What do you mean by "enforce the value"? We enforce that `socket-id` is specified, but not its value.
Yes, We enforce that socket-id is specified.
Surely we can use a name more informative than `INTF_NAME2`. How about `ACCESS_INTF`? We could rename `INTF_NAME` to `TTY_INTF` as well to help differentiate.
yep, done.
Again, let's not just tack a `2` on the end. Name the variables in line with the changes to the macros above.
Done
s/second/access/
Done
Did this need to be moved?
no, fixed it.
this is just `sizeof(sun_path)`, right?

Thats what I had but it was giving compilation error as it treat it as char *.

| In file included from ../../../../../../../../../obmc-console/test/test-client-escape.c:27:
| ../../../../../../../../../obmc-console/console-socket.c: In function 'console_socket_path':
| ../../../../../../../../../obmc-console/console-socket.c:48:33: error: 'sizeof' on array function parameter 'sun_path' will return size of 'char *' [-Werror=sizeof-array-argument]
|    48 |         if ((size_t)rc > (sizeof(sun_path) - 1)) {
|       |                                 ^
| ../../../../../../../../../obmc-console/console-socket.c:31:43: note: declared here
|    31 | ssize_t console_socket_path(socket_path_t sun_path, const char *id)
|       |                             ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~^~~~~~~~

Yeah, okay, that's ... frustrating. But we can still improve it:

https://godbolt.org/z/7jvGa5onr
Done
i.e. we just do `sizeof(sun_path) - 1` here rather than `path_len - 1`.

Thats what I had but it was giving compilation error as it treat it as char *.

| In file included from ../../../../../../../../../obmc-console/test/test-client-escape.c:27:
| ../../../../../../../../../obmc-console/console-socket.c: In function 'console_socket_path':
| ../../../../../../../../../obmc-console/console-socket.c:48:33: error: 'sizeof' on array function parameter 'sun_path' will return size of 'char ' [-Werror=sizeof-array-argument]
| 48 | if ((size_t)rc > (sizeof(sun_path) - 1)) {
| | ^
| ../../../../../../../../../obmc-console/console-socket.c:31:43: note: declared here
| 31 | ssize_t console_socket_path(socket_path_t sun_path, const char id)
By the godbolt link above we can use `sizeof(socket_path_t) - 1` instead.
Done
